page.title: 02COPPLESTONE CROSS
page.content: Copplestone is known for its ancient cross which stands where the three parishes of Down-St-Mary, Colebrook and Crediton Hamlets meet. The markings on the cross represent the murder of the second Bishop of Devonshire around 905. He was killed while on his way to see King Edward. The cross is about 3m high and 50cm square, and is made of granite. The actual cross piece on top of the pillar is missing, though some believe it is in the home of the local M.P. Sir Peter Mills. A few years ago the cross was moved a few metres to the north so that the road could be widened, and it now acts as a traffic island. There are many legends about the cross, which are described on the next page.
